title-group.article-title: Out-of-hours medical care for terminally ill patients: A survey of availability and preferences of general practitioners

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Continuity of care is one of the core values of good medical care for terminally ill patients. The availability of one’s own general practitioner (GP) out of hours is regarded as important for personal continuity. Few data are available about the extent of out-of-hours care given by GPs to their terminally ill patients.

sec.title: Aim:
sec.p: The objective of this study was to determine to which level GPs are available out of hours for their own terminally ill patients and to elicit what factors are relevant to this availability.

sec.title: Design and setting:
sec.p: The research questions were investigated using a cross-sectional study of Dutch GPs. A questionnaire was sent to a random sample of 691 Dutch GPs.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The response rate was 47% (n = 327). Of the respondents, 86% was willing to provide out-of-hours care for their own terminally ill patients. These figures are higher than reported in previous studies. This study shows that out-of-hours availability correlates most strongly with the GPs’ perception of duties of care. Availability is negatively influenced if the GP is in a salaried job, if he or she works in a city based practice, or if home is far from the practice. A correlation between age, sex, and experience of GPs and availability for out-of- hours care for their terminally ill patients was not confirmed.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: The reported out-of-hours availability of GPs for terminally ill patients is still high. GPs’ perception of their duty of care might change in the next generations, and the increasing number of salaried GPs, living far from their practice, might threaten out-of-hours availability for terminally ill patients. sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the Netherlands over a quarter of the population dies at home. More than 45% of patients with cancer in the age group 20–79 years old die at home.1

The general practitioner (GP) is the central health-care provider for terminally ill patients at home. GPs are well prepared for the difficult care they offer during this stage.2,3 The terminal stage is defined as the stage in which it is understood that death will follow shortly, and the patient is mostly bed-ridden. Life-expectancy ranges from days to a few weeks.4
Both medical care and supportive care are crucial parts of terminal care. Most GPs find the intensive contact during the terminally ill phase to be very rewarding.3,5–7

Patients and doctors have the same ideas about what constitutes good care in the last stage of life.8 The availability of a patient’s own GP out of hours is one of the core values of good care, because both patients and doctors regard continuity of care in the terminal phase as important.9–13 There is no clear definition of continuity of care. Continuity of care, as experienced by the patient, is multi-dimensional. In general, three kinds of continuity can be distinguished: continuity of information, management continuity, and personal continuity.14 Personal continuity – the continuity of care which the patient experiences from a doctor whom he or she knows and trusts – stands most to the fore in terminal care.14 The majority of Dutch GPs say they want to be available for their own terminally-ill patients out of hours.9,15 Canadian studies show a positive association between GPs’ personal continuity and the number of people who die at home. More personal care by the GP leads to fewer hospital visits in the terminal phase.16,17

With the ageing population and the increase of patients with cancer, the demand for terminal care from GPs will rise.18 In various Anglo-Saxon countries, appeals are being made to form palliative ‘home-care teams’ for the palliative and/or terminal phase. Advocates argue that GPs are not experienced enough and cannot guarantee continuity.3,19–21

Nowadays, most Dutch GPs participate in large-scale GP co-operatives (Table 1) to provide out-of-hours primary care to their patients.22,23 Few figures are available about the extent of out-of-hours care given by GPs to their terminally ill patients. A small study of five practices in 2003 revealed that less than 10% of patient contact during the terminal phase took place out of hours.6 Other studies show that out of all the contact made with the out-of-hours GP cooperative, only 2.1% involved care for the terminally ill.24,25 Young GPs, who work part-time and are less experienced, spend less time on terminal care.19 A different view of their duties plus the family circumstances of young GPs correlate with the finding that they have less time available to provide out-of-hours terminal care.9,19 GPs in the Netherlands working full-time valued personal continuity of care more than did part-time GPs.25 GP trainees regard continuity of care as important in their work, as their teachers do, but if this care involves working out-of-hours, they have a narrower view of their duties.26 In most research about terminal care out of hours, it was predominantly self-employed GPs who were interviewed, and salaried GPs were underrepresented.3,15

sec.p: Some Australian studies report on logistical difficulties that GPs encounter in rural areas in providing out-of-hours care for terminally ill patients.27,28 GPs in rural areas seem to play a more active role in the care of patients with cancer.29 However, it is not known whether GPs in rural areas are more, or less, available to care for the terminally ill out of hours than GPs in the city.

There are doubts whether the personal continuity of terminal care offered by GPs can be guaranteed in the future. After all, the presence of out-of-hours GP co-operatives may increase the distances between home and work.

Information about GPs’ perception of duties of care and their motivation is essential if we want to anticipate changes in the demand for care and provision of up-to-date care services. We have, therefore, conducted a study based on the two following central questions:

list-item.p: Are GPs available out-of-hours for their own terminally ill patients?
What factors are relevant to this availability?

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The research questions were investigated using a cross-sectional study of Dutch GPs.

sec.title: Measuring instruments
sec.p: The questions were formulated based on data gathered from a literature search and interviews from two GPs. One of them was strongly in favour of, and the other opposed to out-of-hours availability. The concept questionnaire was discussed with senior GPs and GP trainees.
The questions related to:

list-item.p: the personal and demographic features of the GPs and their practices,
out-of-hours availability for terminally ill patients,
the number of terminally ill patients,
the organisation of out-of-hours GP co-operatives.

sec.p: The answers to the questions were set out over a 4-point scale (never/sometimes/regularly/always). Other questions had dichotomous answers (yes/no).

Eighteen statements were also included in the questionnaire. These statements related to the GPs’ perception of duties of care with respect to terminal care out of hours, and their experiences with deputies caring for their terminally ill patients. The optional answers were: totally agree / partly agree / partly disagree / totally disagree.

The questionnaire was presented to four senior GP staff members of the Department of General Practice to improve face and content validity. To test its applicability, 10 GP trainees were first asked to complete the questionnaire.

In the accompanying letter, the definition of terminally ill was given as stated by the Dutch College of General Practitioners: ‘The stage in which it is understood that death will follow shortly, and the patient is mostly bed ridden. Life expectancy ranges from days to a few weeks.’

sec.title: Selection
sec.p: The survey was conducted in spring 2009. For the selection of the study population we used the database of the Netherlands Institute for Health Services Research (NIVEL). The questionnaire was sent to a random sample of 691 GPs from the institute’s 2008 registration list of all Dutch GPs. The sample was stratified for the degree of urbanisation (minimum of 25% rural) and for the percentage of salaried GPs (minimum, the national average of 12% in each grade of urbanisation). Because the study was anonymous, reminders were sent to all GPs after 4 weeks. Ethical approval was not required.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: The collected data were analysed using the SPSS statistical package.

A new variable for availability was computed from the scores of four sub-questions about availability. With this new variable the extent to which the respondent was available could be qualified on an interval scale. The minimum score on this question was 4 (never available) and the maximum score was 16 (always available to all terminally ill patients). The internal consistency of the new scale was high with a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.91. The new variable of availability was then used in the univariate and multiple regression analysis.

A factor analysis of the statements was completed to assess whether the 18 statements from the questionnaire could be represented in a few underlying dimensions. To this end, a number of negative statements were inverted so all scores could be compared. Based on the screeplot the number of factors for factor analysis was determined and subsequently rotated according to the varimax criterion. Next, the explained variance was calculated and Cronbach’s alpha coefficients were determined. A reliability coefficient of greater than 0.6 was considered acceptable.

The mutual relationships between the different variables was tested by using non-parametric tests (the Chi-square test and the Mann–Whitney U-test) and parametric tests (the T-test). The relationship between continuous variables was examined using Pearson’s correlation coefficient. A p-value of < 0.05 was considered to be significant.

The influence of the personal and practice characteristics related to availability was examined using a multiple linear regression analysis. The backward criterion was used to select the explanatory variables.30,31

sec.title: Characteristics of the respondents
sec.p: The response rate was 47% (n = 327). The average age of the respondents was 48 years (standard deviation [SD] 8.4). The percentage of female GPs in the study was 36%. These and other GP and practice characteristics of the respondents are set out in Table 2.

sec.p: Over the past year, according to the GPs, they gave care to an average of 6.9 (SD 6.0) terminally ill patients. The GPs who were available to their patients were asked to give out-of-hours care to terminally ill patients 7.3 (SD 8.1) times in 2008.
Almost all the respondents (96.6%) were affiliated to an out-of-hours GP cooperative.

sec.title: Out-of-hours availability
sec.p: Of the respondents, 86% were willing to be available out of hours for their own terminally ill patients. The extent to which the respondents were available is shown in Figure 1. Three quarters (76.3%) of the respondents stated that they were available regularly, or at all times, for patients who had a life expectancy of less than 2 weeks, and 42.6% of the GPs were available at all times for patients with whom they had a special bond.

caption.p: Percentage of general practitioners (GPs) who are available for their terminally ill patients out of hours.

sec.p: The GPs who were available for their terminally ill patients out of hours were very positive about the contact with these patients. The contact out of hours was perceived as valuable, and abuse of the GP’s private telephone number was rare.

Of all the respondents, 64.2% said that being available at all times to their terminally ill patients was too great a burden, and 56.2% said that being available 24 hours a day for their patients was an outdated concept.

sec.title: Factor analysis
sec.p: In factor analysis of the statements, four factors produced the best results. We labelled them as follows:

list-item.p: Factor 1 ‘Perception of duties of care’ comprises six statements and measures GPs’ willingness to be available for their terminally ill patients out of hours (Crohnbach’s alpha 0.78).

Factor 2 was dubbed ‘Dissatisfaction’ and comprises five statements. It measures concerns on own performance while providing care for terminally ill patients of a colleague out of hours (Crohnbach’s alpha 0.68).

Factor 3 ‘Differences in care provision’ comprises three statements and measures the degree to which GPs find that the care given to their terminally ill patients by a colleague out of hours differs from their own approach (Crohnbach’s alpha 0.64).
Factor 4 ‘Rewards’ comprises three statements on the importance respondents attach to continuity, and the satisfaction the terminal care may give.

sec.p: Almost all the respondents (99%) considered continuity of care in the terminal phase to be very important, and 97% indicated that giving this care was very rewarding. Because of this large measure of agreement, the internal consistency of factor 4 was too low (Crohnbach’s alpha 0.48), and it was removed from the analysis.
Factors 1 to 3 explain 42% of the total variance. The results of factors 1 to 3 are given in Table 3.

sec.title: Differences in availability, univariate analysis (Tables 4 and 5)
sec.p: The extent of out-of-hours availability was clearly associated with a number of personal and practice characteristics. Men scored significantly higher on availability than women (p = 0.005), self-employed GPs scored higher than salaried GPs (p <0.001), GPs working in a group practice scored lower than GPs in single-handed or two-GP practices (p < 0.001), and rural GPs scored higher than city-based GPs (p = 0.014).

sec.p: A relatively strong correlation existed between availability and factor 1 ‘Perception of duties of care’ (r = 0.66). There was a correlation >0.25 between availability and factor 2 ‘Dissatisfaction’, the number of hours the GP worked, and the distance between home address and practice (negative correlation). The correlation of age of the respondent, ages of any children and experience as a GP with availability was less strong.

sec.title: Differences in availability, multiple linear regression analysis (Table 6)
sec.p: Analysis of the residuals showed that the conditions for regression analysis were met. Ten explanatory variables were included in the regression model.

If factor 1 ‘Perception of duties of care’ had been included in the multiple regression model, it overshadowed all the other explanatory variables for availability. For this reason, this factor was not included in the regression model.

After all variables were selected in accordance with the backward criterion, three variables finally remained which predicted the score on the availability scale. These variables were: whether the practice was rural or city-based; whether the GP was salaried; and the distance from home to practice. These variables explained 14% of the total variance.

sec.title: Most important findings
sec.p: Almost all GPs regard continuity of care in the terminal phase as important and find it very rewarding to provide such care. A clear majority of the GPs indicated that they want to be available for their terminally ill patients out of hours. This study shows that GPs who score higher on perception of duties of care and are more willing to be available out of hours, score higher on availability. Being a salaried GP, working in an urban practice or living far from the practice has a significant negative influence on out-of-hours availability for terminal patients.

In the univariate analysis, the GP’s gender and the amount of working hours per week appear to have significant influence on GPs’ availability. In the multiple regression analysis, however, these differences disappear. The GP’s age and years of experience as a GP also prove to have no influence.

sec.title: Strong points and limitations of this study
sec.p: The response to this study was moderate, but the group of respondents reflected the population of Dutch GPs well (Table 1). A major non-response bias may have taken place; it is known that GPs with an interest in the topic are more likely to respond, though other factors might have influenced the response.32 A non-respondent analysis could not be done, because of the anonymous character of the study.

Because the study relies on self-reported behaviour, there is a risk that socially desirable responses were given. On the other hand, the respondents could express themselves freely as the study was anonymous.

We found a strong correlation between out-of-hours availability and perception of duties of care. Though the internal consistency of this factor 1 was good, there is no ‘gold standard’ to measure perception of duties of care for general practitioners.

sec.title: General discussion
sec.p: The found level of out-of-hours availability for terminally ill patients in this study is as high or higher than was found in previous studies.9,15 The relation of out-of-hours availability with age or gender of the GP, with years of experience or part-time factor, could not be confirmed in this study. This contradicts previous studies.9,15

Continuity of care in the last stage of life might be still warranted if the level of availability remains as high as was found in this study. More and more GPs are in salaried employment.33 The organisation of evening, night and weekend duties via the out-of-hours GP co-operatives enables GPs to live farther away from their practice. It could be that the percentage of GPs who are available, which currently is still high at 86%, will decrease in the future. This will depend largely on their perception of duties of care, as this study shows that the factor ‘Perception of duties of care’ carries more weight in terms of availability than any personal or practice characteristics. The Dutch College of GPs recently formulated a mission statement that all GPs should be available 24 hours a day for their own terminally ill patients (http://nhg.artsennet.nl/kenniscentrum/k_implementatie/k_nhgstandpunten-toekomstvisie.htm). This statement might influence the perception of duties of care of Dutch GPs.

The perceived burden of care is an issue which requires attention. GPs report a great degree of availability and regard their work in the terminal phase as very rewarding. At the same time, the majority indicates that they regard the burden of such care as being too great, and more than half regards 24-hours per day availability as an outdated concept. This carries the danger of stress and frustration.34 GPs previously indicated that providing terminal care in the context of a GP co-operative is challenging, but being on call 24 hours is not preferable at all.35

sec.title: Implications for the future
sec.p: In this study we investigated the out-of-hours availability for own terminal patients, we did not study the quality of care. More research is required to determine the quality of out-of-hours care given to terminally ill patients by GPs working through GP co-operatives. Other ways of guaranteeing continuity of care for terminally ill patients could be developed and tested.
The GP’s perception of duties of care is a relevant factor to the provision of care. Tools should be developed to measure this perception of duties of care in a more standardised way.

The opinion of patients and their carers about the care given requires further investigation. Publications about this aspect are rather scarce or date from before the introduction of the out-of-hours GP co-operatives.35,36

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Eighty-six percent of the Dutch GPs are available out of hours for their own terminally ill patients. This study shows that out-of-hours availability is closely related to their perception of duties of care and is influenced in a negative way: if they are in a salaried job; if they work in a city-based practice; and if their home is far from their practice.

Personal continuity of care is a core value of good terminal care. The way GPs perceive their duty of care might change in the next generations, and the increasing number of salaried GPs living far from their practice might further threaten out-of-hours availability for terminally ill patients.
